final_poem:
# Verbatim

The first day came and I didn't recognize it—
the thermometer's shy crook, the pavement
softening under the weight of its own memory.

Birds. They were always there but now they
had something to say about it. A sound
less like speech than the mechanism of a gate
lifting. The yard was alive with tuck and call,
each one placing a stone on top of another
in that stack we keep without deciding to.

I cut the grass once and it looked wrong—
a silence afterward, the sort of quiet
that makes you think someone is watching.
But no one. Just the lawn, flat under its white coat,
waiting for rain to give it color back.

The river found its banks again,
which was not the same as saying
it settled into them. The water moved
like a sentence that has finally landed on a period—
complete but still going somewhere.

I held a dandelion stem and watched
the clock inside it open, each puff
more precise than mine had ever been.
That's how spring is: not the doing,
but the witnessing of what already knows
how to happen. The asterions letting go,
the ice breaking in one place only
so the lake can breathe while still holding together.

I put my coat on without thinking about it.
The season must have claimed my hands
while I was sleeping. And when you sleep
inside a season long enough, something happens
to the way you open your eyes—
you notice the light before you notice being awake,
and that is almost religious,
isn't it, that almost?

I walked to the garden gate.
It hadn't been locked. The yard was green
in patches now, the grasses pushing up through
what remained of last year's argument.

I sat on the step. A cardinal hopped across
the path and did not flinch at me—
only adjusted its red, as if saying:
*You're here already?*

The air tasted like it meant something.
Like a sentence that has rehearsed itself
across all of January, February,
and now March is just the part
where you catch your breath in the middle.

I stayed there until five o'clock,
which was dark. The dark was particular—
not the dark before but the one
that agrees, that nods its whole body
toward silence and stays.

And after dark, the first frogs.
They had been practicing all winter
in some deep pond under everything,
and now they were ready to say it clean,
the way only animals can, without
once sounding like anything else—
just the sound, which is almost godlike,
which is almost the definition of permission.

I stood up. The step was cold.
The dandelion still in my hand
had gone ahead and done what I couldn't—
it had opened into something
neither flower nor cloud but the idea
of going soft enough to rise.
